Introduction
The Trust has a duty to ensure that all employees are paid the correct salary, allowances and benefits.
Occasionally errors occur and employees are either under or overpaid salary, allowances, expenses or benefits. The Trust has a responsibility to ensure that errors are duly corrected.

The purpose of this policy is to outline the procedures in place to reimburse under payments and recover over payments should this occur, clarify the legal position which enables the Trust to do so and to ensure that staff are aware of the Trust position and their responsibilities.

The Trust will take appropriate action against any employee who has been found to have dishonestly or knowingly retained an overpayment of salary. The employee's action may result in disciplinary action and / or criminal proceedings.
Scope

The purpose of this policy is to outline the Trust's approach to under and overpayments of pay, allowances and benefits. The aim is to ensure that the action taken when dealing with such matters is in a consistent, fair and transparent manner.

This policy applies to all employees of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust working through a permanent, fixed term or bank contract. Overpayments to workers not paid via the Trust (such as locums) will be recovered through the agency who manages their employment. The Trust will seek to rectify any errors regardless of when the error occurred.

This policy is in accordance with Section 14 of the Employment Rights Act 1996 which confirms the legal position that the Trust is not prevented from recovering an overpayment by deducting it from an employee's future wages or salary.
Definitions

table_items.text: Includes salary, expenses and any other re-imbursements e.g sick pay, maternity pay, annual leave.
Where an employee, ex-employee, fixed term or bank worker is paid an amount in excess of their contractual entitlement.
Where an employee, ex-employee, fixed term or bank worker is paid an amount less than their contractual entitlement.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Audit Committee duties are to receive reports on the losses arising from overpayments that are to be written off in accordance with the Trust's Standing Financial Instructions and Standing Orders.
Chief Finance Officer Duties are:
Authorise the recovery terms of overpayments in accordance with the Trust's Standing Financial Instructions and Standing Orders.
Responsible for approving repayment plans if overpayment recovery is extended beyond the next salary payment.
Human Resources Department Duties are:
Ensure that the information is input into the Electronic Staff Record (ESR) system in an accurate and timely manner within the agreed and published timetable.
Ensure that employees are made aware of any appropriate salary changes in writing.
Ensure this policy is followed fairly and consistently, by processing all appointment, termination and change forms on receipt to ensure under and over payments are avoided and/or minimised.
Monitor under and over payments
Ensure matters are dealt with in accordance with current employment legislation and good practice.
Provide advice on processes to managers and staff.

Responsible for discussing a repayment plan with an employee. In the event of a dispute or financial hardship recommend to the Chief Finance Officer a suitable repayment plan for agreement with the employee.
Payroll services – NHS Shared Business Services (SBS) It is the responsibility of the payroll provider to:
Ensure that information is put into ESR in an accurate and timely manner (within agreed Roles and Responsibilities document).
Ensure any payment errors are resolved following agreed payroll procedures.
Ensure any payment errors are identified and the employee advised in a timely manner.(overpayment and underpayments)
Follow this procedure in resolving payment errors.
Duties are:
Ensure that once overpayments or underpayments have been identified they are notified to the employee, HR and Finance in a timely manner in line with salary period of issue. agreed procedures.
Monitor both Trust and SBS Payroll performance regarding accuracy and escalate as appropriate through the monthly provision of the overpayment register and KPI report to key contacts.
In adherence with the ‘Agreement for the provision of NHS Shared Services', SBS Payroll will be responsible for the following:
To perform the calculation of an over or under payment.

To write to the employee with an explanation of discrepancy. For example, providing an overpayment breakdown and schedule for recovery or repayment. A copy of which, must be sent to Finance and Human Resources.
To amend subsequent payment details for next pay run once repayment plan is agreed with the employee.
To implement the recovery of the payment from employee through payroll, once agreed.
If overpayment recovery is not possible via payroll, to inform the Finance department to initiate alternative repayment options including formal debt recovery if required.
To produce a monthly summary of overpayments recovered and underpayments made; including the reason for them; analysed by reason for error.
If an underpayment arose to be resolved within the same pay period.
Finance Department Duties are:
Ensure that overpayments that are not to be recovered through the payroll are recovered in line with the Trust Policy and are referred through the debtor's process as appropriate.
Monitor under and over payments and review debts to ensure they are being chased appropriately.
Managers Duties are:

Ensure compliance with the policy and all relevant Trust budgetary and establishment control procedures, checking their budget statements to ensure that staff who have left their department are not still being paid.
Ensure that relevant staff pay related documentation (starter, change or termination forms) are completed and forwarded to HR in a timely manner.
Obtaining immediate advice from HR should they have a belief that an employee has been overpaid or underpaid?

Seek advice from HR where special circumstances and communicate with the employee to discuss the recovery action suggested by SBS Payroll or adjustment to pay in respect of an overpayment or underpayment.
Clear Healthroster exceptions regularly and authorise payroll within required timescales every month to ensure staff are paid correctly.
Providing support where possible to the employee if an overpayment/underpayment has occurred (e.g. referral to CIC Employee Assistance Programme).
Employees Duties are:
Check payments and benefits and bring any anomalies to the attention of their manager.
To follow any Trust procedures required to record hours worked and claiming payment.

Ensure that they are aware of their contractual obligations and to advise the Trust of any changes that may affect their pay, for example, change of hours, unpaid absences or completion of a contract.
Ensure they understand their salary entitlement.

Regardless of the cause of an overpayment, whether it be system or human error, the employee has a duty to declare to their Line Manager and either SBS Payroll or the Human Resources Department and repay the amount in full once they become aware of it.
Local Counter Fraud Specialist Duties are:

Investigate all overpayments that may be considered fraudulent. All NHS Trusts are duty bound by the Public Accounts Committee to recover overpayments in full; where significant overpayments occur then the Local Counter Fraud Specialist will be asked to investigate the case as suspected fraud or theft.
The Theft Act (1978) indicates that although an individual may not set out to

obtain the additional salary intentionally, by dishonestly keeping it and treating it as their own, for example, by spending it, then they will be guilty of theft. Counter Fraud Investigations will include contacting the individual
Process
Employee rights.
To be paid correctly.
To be notified as soon as possible by either their line manager or a member of the SBS Payroll provider that an incorrect payment has been identified.
To have the matter dealt with in a sensitive manner.
In the case of overpayment or underpayment, to receive clear and unambiguous details of the amount, the reason for the overpayment and the period involved.
To be accompanied by a trade union representative, colleague or friend at and formal meetings to discuss the incorrect payment.
To be given the opportunity to consider the information provided before having to respond.
Employees have the right to make any appropriate representations regarding their personal circumstances; however the repayment period will be determined by the Chief Finance Officer.
There are a number of ways in which an employee can be incorrectly paid, including, but not restricted to:
An overpayment of salary
An underpayment of salary
Payment of incorrect travel or non-travel expenses
Duplication of a payment
Deduction made in error

Where an overpayment or underpayment is discovered, it is the responsibility of SBS Payroll or the Trust Transaction team who has discovered the overpayment or underpayment, to ensure that all other relevant parties are also notified. These relevant parties being SBS Payroll, Finance, the line manager and the HR Business Partner.
As previously set out in 3.7, it is the expectation that an employee will notify their line manager and the payroll department when they discover an under/overpayment.
The likely causes of an overpayment include, but are not restricted to:
A termination notification not being completed, received or processed on time
Late or lack of notification of sickness absence
Staff not returning from maternity leave
An error being made
A late change notification
Incorrect salary banding
Staff still in employment

Salaries are paid through the Electronic Staff Record (ESR). Adjustments to pay are made automatically by the ESR system upon receipt of the relevant instruction via a change form from the relevant manager. If the overpayment identified relates only to the previous month, this will be recovered in the next months' pay.

If an overpayment is for a longer period of time the overpayment will still normally be rectified in the following month's pay through the ESR system. However if the change to an employees pay results in an overpayment being identified which is over 20% of the employee's net pay this will be identified to the HR Department by the Payroll provider (SBS).
The employee will be written to by the payroll provider (SBS) to inform them the overpayment has occurred and of its value. The letter will also contain the overpayment repayment plan.

If the employee considers that the repayment plan in their overpayment letter is not viable, either due to exceptional circumstances or that they dispute the claim, then the employee will have the responsibility of contacting the Human Resources Department, to discuss this and propose a revised repayment plan. If this occurs and is deemed to be a reasonable request, the deductions will be suspended until an investigation has been completed or an alternative repayment plan is agreed. The repayment plan must be a reasonable suggestion from the employee and should not stray too far from the period of time in which the overpayment occurred. The employee has  days from the receipt of the letter to contact the HR department before the repayment plan is actioned.

The duration of the repayment plan may reasonably be proposed to be the same as the length of time the overpayment has occurred i.e. a member of staff who has been overpaid for 4 months could be proposed as the period to repay the amount by deductions from salary over four months by approximately equal deductions.
Longer repayment plans will only be made in exceptional circumstances and with the express agreement of the Chief Finance Officer.
The Payroll provider (SBS) will be responsible for making the relevant deductions directly from the member of staff's pay on receipt of the repayment plan.

To request an alternative payment plan due to financial hardship, the employee should contact their Trust HR Manager in writing. This will involve submission of statements to evidence their financial hardship (See “NHS SBS Overpayments User Guide” (Appendix B for details of the procedure).

The Trust may consider changes to an agreed repayment plan, if an individual's circumstances change substantially by incidents outside their control, for example, maternity leave or long term sickness. These requests are considered on an individual basis (refer to the NHS SBS Overpayments User Guide (Appendix B)).

If an employee unreasonably refuses to make repayments in relation to a salary overpayment, then by law the Trust is permitted to make deductions through the Payroll without the individual's permission. This is in line with the Employee Relations Act (1996) and Employment Right Act (1996).

If an outstanding overpayment exists at the point of termination of contract, the final balance will be deducted from the employee's final salary payment. If there is a shortfall, in these circumstances Section 5.3 will be enacted.
When an underpayment has been identified, action should be taken as quickly as possible to rectify the error and ESR updated accordingly.
Any manual payment requests should be made in reference to the qualifying criteria set out in section 8
Staff no longer employed by the trust and bank workers
For an unrecovered overpayment to an ex-employee, an invoice will be raised and sent to the ex-employee/or bank worker together with appropriate information identifying the basis of the overpayment.

For ex-employees/or bank worker where an overpayment has been found, they will be provided with written notice of the background to the overpayment, the amount, and immediate payment demanded. The address will be the last known home address held on ESR. Payment will be requested within  days.

To request an alternative payment plan due to financial hardship, the ex- employee/or bank worker should contact the Trust's Accounts Receivable Team. This will involve the submission of appropriate documentation to evidence their financial hardship; depending on the circumstances of the request.
If no response is received from the ex-employee within the stipulated  days, the Trust's normal Debt Recovery Procedure will then be followed for the amount outstanding.
Ex-employees who unreasonably refuse to repay overpayments may be subject to action as set out in Section
Underpayments
An underpayment is where an employee, or an ex-employee, is underpaid in respect of salary to what they are due under their contractual or statutory entitlement.
The likely causes of an underpayment include, but are not restricted to:
A variation to contract notification being submitted or processed after payroll cut off
A late change notification
An error being made
Incorrect salary banding
Late submission of expense claims, excess hours, enhancements, overtime.
Underpayments will be repaid to the employee through the next available payroll run or within 5 working days in line with their normal pay frequency once the full information has been established.
In exceptional circumstances, arrangements may be put in place to reimburse employees sooner than later.
Any manual payment requests should be made with reference to the qualifying criteria set out in Section 7.1 and Appendix 1 of this policy.
Manual payments

Manual payments are by definition a temporary payment for appropriate cases until the next available payroll run takes place and should be used as an emergency facility. Until a payroll run takes place, a manual payment will only release a standard 60% of the total gross amount due (to allow for standard PAYE, National Insurance and Pension to be taken formally). It should be noted that the manual payment amount may be reduced further if the employee is in a high tax bracket or is subject to increased national insurance or pension contributions.

The gross payment will then be put through the next available payroll run and adjusted accordingly for deductions. Any further arrears that may be due would therefore be paid in the next available payroll run.

Manual payments can be requested by an employee's Line Manager in exceptional circumstances to the HR Department for consideration. Payment requests will be assessed on an individual case basis and Manager's should be aware that payment may be deferred to the next available payroll run, if the request is categorised as non-urgent. Please review the Manual Payment Decision Pathway (Appendix 1) for an overview of the decision process.

If an employee is in receipt of nil pay or missing a significant amount of their contracted pay; then the employee will be eligible for an urgent manual payment at the earliest possible opportunity once the form has been received from SBS Payroll and authorised for payment.

To raise a manual payment caused by Manager or Employee delay or error, there is a bank standard charge which is payable by the budget holder for that department. Manual payments cannot be made for amounts under £50 (Net) under any circumstances
Wilful misrepresentation by the employee

If an overpayment of salary is caused because the employee has wilfully misrepresented facts or relevant data, all possible steps must be taken to effect immediate recovery, which may include investigation by the Local Counter Fraud. (Refer to Section  for clarification regarding action in this event)
Counter fraud
Employees alleged to be involved in fraudulent activity may render themselves liable to disciplinary action, including termination of employment.

Employees must be aware that failure to provide a true declaration when asked by the Trust, or the making of a false declaration, could result in an investigation by the Local Counter Fraud Specialist, which could lead to disciplinary and/or criminal/civil action.
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
Monitoring and audit
Records of overpayments will be produced by SBS Payroll and maintained by the Finance department.

Copies of all letters and correspondence that SBS Payroll send to staff (both current and ex-employees) will be forwarded to the Human Resources team who will monitor that actions taken are consistent as per this policy.
Monthly reviews of payroll discrepancies will be held by the Head of Human Resources and Head of Financial Accounting.
There will be a monthly analysis of payroll overpayments to include any necessary actions and investigations undertaken.
Internal/external audit review will be undertaken as required in addition to periodic review by the Audit Committee.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This policy will be implemented with SBS as part of the standardised contract for Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust. These will then be forwarded to the HR Policy Working Group for local approval before being submitted to the Document control team for review and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the employees of MSE of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all, respecting the needs and privacy of individuals while also protecting the interests and privacy of others. An equality impact assessment relating to this policy is attached in appendix 3, which shows that this policy impacts on all protected groups equally and without barriers occurring. (Refer to appendix 3)
